Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2010 07:37PM katsOK wrote: Hi Sweeney  I kept my hands in ice water and think that is what saved my nails since  I did lose my big toe nails months after I finished chemo.  My eyebrows have never returned in any great numbers but I had thin eyebrows anyway just much thinnner now.  I ate a lot of watermelon, the taste was ok and I had trouble with water tasting like metal.  Had to watch for constipation since I had it on first round.  By third  treatment I was having stomach troubles around the 9th to 10th day ended up in the hospital once overnight with it.  Really had to watch the spicy foods and fatty foods.  I did not work during the treatment but did not have a lot of energy however I am older also.  My grandkids liked to put my wig on and they thought it was funny for me to take it off and put it back on, great entertainment for them.   I agree the thing I remember the most is how slowly hair grows back in.  It is over yet you still have this bald head, I had trouble having patience with the process.  My hair is back and I have lost most of the chemo hair that you get at first (very fine).   I still have some chemo brain but again I am older so maybe it is harder to shake when in your sixties.  Good Luck and remember we all say it is doable.
Posts.Title: TC chemo- what can i expect? sweeney Anna2017

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2012 10:39AM - edited Aug 19, 2012 11:04AM by katsOK I will miss Dawn and her voice here. She was so kind to me while I was waiting to find out if I had mets or just a severely collasped T-12. She helped me try to recover without surgery which I did. I was not a good candidate for the surgery so so glad I had her help sorting out what would help such as using a back brace, having good pain control and just waiting it out. Knowing it was possible to heal helped me deal with it all. Condolences to her family on their loss. Kathleen

Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2009 11:42AM katsOK wrote: I finished my chemo TC about 3 weeks ago and am becoming very nervous and depressed about my hair not returning.  I have no reason to think it will not return but seem to be obcessing over the possibility.  I go to see my onocologist next week about AL's and that has me upset also.  Do not want one that will make my hair thin  or manke me gain weight but want one that will work well at keeping the cancer away...  I have not been in this much turmoil since my diagnosis and all the stuff going on then.   I keep saying the serenity prayer but go right back into my obcessing over losing my hair, what the Al's will do to me hair wise and weight wise.  I am trying to not eat over any of this since I also need to lose weight, not gain weight.   Just wanted to vent, know you guys cannot solve this or take this anxiety away from me.  Somehow I have got to calm myself down.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2009 08:57AM - edited Jun 12, 2009 09:36AM by katsOK Good morning, I had my chemo yesterday and I am doing great.  No nausea to speak of and just a little pain in back and arms.  I was able to go out and walk this am. for 20 minutes and plan to do some inside exercises today also.  I had some trouble sleeping last night mainly pain off the port I had put in on the 10th.  Had trouble finding a comfortable spot to sleep with it still being sensitive.  I am scheduled for blood work this next thursday and the next monday after that.  I guess with my age of 66, that is the biggest concern:  my white blood cells going too low.  So will be up there every week until it is time for second chemo.  I am glad I live near and do not have to travel far.  Kathleen
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2009 04:06PM katsOK wrote: This is my third day and still very little nausea but lots of back, arm and leg pains.  LIke a case of the flu.... I have tried some medicines and none work for long.  I wonder how long this will last.  I was on taxotere and carboplatin but I heard from the nurse I will change next time to taxotere and cytoxan.  THe onc only wants to do chemo for 4 times and so rethought the treatment.  THe carboplain and the cytoxan I believe are very similar but am still wondering if my symptoms will change with the change.  More chances of weight gain with the cytoxan than the carbolpain from what I understand and I do not need to gain any weight.   But 4 times is better than 6 since I am so achey.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2009 11:06AM katsOK wrote: My ER was 98% on final pathology, the PR was 12% on final pathology and the Ki67 was 7%.  However on the biospy pathology my PR was 72% and the Ki67 was 16%.  My oncotype was a 27.  I wish I knew what they clasified my Ki67 as being on the oncotype since it is one of the factors they test. Also, I was a grade 3 on final pathology.  I went ahead and did TC x 4 chemotherapy and will go on Arimidex next month.  I do not know if I am a luminal A or B since my PR was not high and there is such a range on the Ki67.  I may ask my onocologist if she can find out what my Ki67 was on the oncotype test.  Although psychologically it might be better if I did not know since the prognosis is not as good for luminal B and I have done and am doing everything I can think of to keep this at bay.  It would be nice to know if one type of chemotherapy was better for luminal B's.  Maybe someday they will know that even if will not help me.
Posts.Title: making friends with your path report weesa Pure

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2010 06:03PM katsOK wrote: I never lost all my eyebrows with chemo but very few came back of the ones I lost.  I was already eyebrow challenged and had had them tatooed years ago.  I went in last month and had them re-tatooed ( the tatooing does not last on me for some reason, skin chemistry or some medication I use, is what I was told)   i am sure it will fade with time and I will have to do it again.  Always an option if you get tired of drawing them on.  Be sure to go to someone who is recommended to you, they vary in their ability to make them natural.  i talked to several people before I decided on the person, she is a nurse and is in a physician's office.   Also do not go close to an MRI appointment, you have to have had it done a few months or weeks before you can have an MRI.  At least that is what  I was told my the breast MRI nurse when I asked her about it.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: May 3, 2011 06:04PM katsOK wrote:  Hi, I read the last couple of pages and thought I would add my information... my eyebrow fell out and very few have come back 18 months later.  I have had some tatooed on but to be honest I did not have alot of eyebrows to begin with; however, lots more than I have now.  My eyelashes  came back but seem shorter to me.   My hair is thin on top and crown but it was thin  before chemo also.  I use Rogaine once a day but do not know if it is helping or not.  I started after my hair started growing back in and I had started Arimidex. I had read that arimidex could make hair thin if you were predisposed to thinning.. Do not use it twice a day since it is a bllod pressure medicine and my blood pressure was low on it.  I read that once a day does about as much as twice a day.

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2011 08:33AM katsOK wrote: So sorry to hear about your progression, I was hoping the diabetic drug and the hormonal  drug were going to be the next best thing for all of us.  Hoping the Tamoxifen does the trick and makes the cells go to sleep, a long long sleep or as your shirt says makes them die!!
Posts.Title: Sighhhhhhhh.......crap Chickadee Frapp

Posts.Content: May 3, 2011 05:50PM katsOK wrote: Hi, I finished chemo over 18 months ago (Aug 09) and my hair has come back in, it is about the same color, the same curl, almost as thick BUT the texture is terrible.  It is dry, dry, dry and it not the same type hair I had before.  I do not know if this is an after effect of the chemo or caused by the arimidex.  I asked my hair dresser about it last week and she sold me a product called "It's a 10, a miracle leave-in product"....  and  for the first time my hair looks normal and soft.  Do not know if others have the same problem but thought I would pass this information along.  I had purchased several products and they would work for a few hours and then it would look dry again.  So glad to finally find something that works.

Posts.Title: New Drug Prevents Reoccurence by 65%!!!! Pure ktym

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2009 11:00AM katsOK wrote: I had a IDC and it was found on mammogram or really on ultrasound.  The doctor said she was suspicious of the area (dense breast tissue) so did the ultrasound after watching the area for at least a year!!  I would not have known it was there if I had not know it was there.... and that was after four cores taken from it and it was swollen.  The shape was like an arrowhead and not moveable and hard.  Went in the direction that a muscle might go and in location where a muscle might be.  The surgeon said she did not think she would have found it if she had not know where to look.  It was 2.5 cm and at first they thought it might be 4 cm.  It was in the lower outside quadrant of the right breast.  You had to push hard to feel; it much harder than I thought you had to push to examine you.  It makes me doubt my ability to find anything in the other breast or other areas of the right breast.  I am hoping for good exams from the doctors to help me in the future.
Posts.Title: WHAT did YOUR lump FEEL like? gscott MomOfTeenGirl01

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2011 10:07AM katsOK wrote: Hi, before I had breast cancer I did have a problem with my parathyroid and had surgery on it.  I never had a calcium test that was extremely high just on the high side of normal, and the test for hyperparthyroid was not extremely high either.  I did have osteopenia and when tested had high levels of calcium in my urine.  My kidneys were doing a good job keeping the calicum levels "normal" in my blood and I am lucky I did not develop kidney stones which is how a lot of people find out the have a parthyroid problem.   I did educate myself on the parthyroid.com site but had my surgery locally.   Hope this helps and if they do  not find anything, you might ask for a 24 hour urine test.
Posts.Title: gosh...what next... weesa weesa

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2012 10:18PM katsOK wrote: Lack of estrogen, having had children, fluids in the evening all can cause urinary incontinence in the older woman.  I don't leak at night but  sometimes start leaking trying to get to the bathroom when I get up in the night or first thing in the morning.  There is a pill you can take that helps or you can limit fluids in the evenings or wear a incontinence pad.  It might be because of spinal mets but I would think it would be all the time in that case.  Lots of women who do not have cancer have the problem when they reach menopause.  Son in law is an urologist so got some free advise.  He did not mention the fluid in the evening but I found by limiting it my problem is better.  If I am worried when I go to bed I wear a pad.
Posts.Title: Spine Lesion - "Bedwetting"? Hello12 usafmom

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2012 09:23AM katsOK wrote: I have never connected the loss of a lumpy spot on my chin with my chemo but it must have been when it went away... I had it for probably close to 20 years.  Thank you coolbreeze for mentioning it.  I have a skin condition on my scalp that got much better during chemo and has never been as bad as it was before, since then.  I also enjoyed the not shaving my legs during chemo and since then I have had a decrease in the amount of leg hairs but do have to shave again.    It has been tradeoffs for me, toenails worse and texture of hair not as nice but toes can be covered and I do have hair now!!  Kathleen

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2010 09:04AM katsOK wrote: Day - the Brassica Tea is at the health food store called Akins in OKC.  It is located at 63rd and May and I believe there is one on Memorial near SAM'S.  Johns Hopkins recommends breast cancer patients drink it several times a day.  I forget to do that most days and I think it's taste is a little off to me.  But your taste buds may be different than mine.  They also have a sprout growing jar there to grow spouts in.  Kat43
